headline.print_headline: Eric Gregg, 55, Longtime Major League Umpire Who Battled Weight Problems
headline.main: Eric Gregg, Umpire Who Battled Weight Problems, Dies at 55

docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Gregg umpired in the major leagues for more than two decades while battling a craving for food and drink that spotlighted health concerns surrounding overweight umpires.
docs.snippet: Eric Gregg umpired in the major leagues for more than two decades while battling a craving for food and drink that spotlighted health concerns surrounding overweight umpires.

headline.print_headline: A Few Extra Pounds May Raise Acid Reflux Risk
headline.main: Connections: A Few Extra Pounds May Raise Acid Reflux Risk

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who gain weight may increase their risk of gastroesophageal reflux disease, a new study suggests.
docs.snippet: Women who gain weight may increase their risk of gastroesophageal reflux disease, a new study suggests.

docs.abstract: So who are these "food police" we're starting to hear so much about? The term has begun showing up in media accounts of campaigns to reform school lunch or in discussions of the food industry's growing legion of critics in the media. It's the "food police" who want to get soda out of the schools [...]
docs.lead_paragraph: So who are these "food police" we're starting to hear so much about? The term has begun showing up in media accounts of campaigns to reform school lunch or in discussions of the food industry's growing legion of critics in the media. It's the "food police" who want to get soda out of the schools and who argue that fast food outlets should disclose nutritional information about what they sell. The "food police" supposedly want to take away your constitutional right to a Big Mac - or, at the very least, your right to enjoy a Big Mac with a clear conscience.

headline.print_headline: Obesity Letters Having Effect In Arkansas
headline.main: Obesity Letters Having Effect in Arkansas

docs.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 3 (AP) — It has been two years since Arkansas schools started sending letters home to parents with students' report cards telling them if their children were overweight.
docs.snippet: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 3 (AP) — It has been two years since Arkansas schools started sending letters home to parents with students' report cards telling them if their children were overweight.
